t: Isaiah 5
Song of the Vineyard
I*pn will sing about the one I love, a*ln song about my loved one’s vineyard: The*ln one I love had a vineyard on*ln a very fertile hill.

He*ln broke up the soil, cleared it of stones, and*ln planted it with the finest vines. He*ln built a tower in the middle of it and*ln even dug out a winepress there. He*ln expected it to yield good grapes, but*ln it yielded worthless grapes.
So*pn now, residents of Jerusalem and*ln men of Judah, please*ln judge between me and*ln my vineyard.
What*ln more could I have done for my vineyard than*ln I did? Why,*ln when I expected a yield of good grapes, did*ln it yield worthless grapes?
Now*ln I will tell you what*ln I am about to do to my vineyard: I*ln will remove its hedge, and*ln it will be consumed; I*ln will tear down its wall, and*ln it will be trampled.
I*ln will make it a wasteland. It*ln will not be pruned or weeded; thorns*ln and briers will grow up. I*ln will also give orders to the clouds that*ln rain should not fall on it.

For*ln the vineyard of the Lord*s of Armies is*ln the house of Israel, and*ln the men of Judah, the*ln plant he delighted in. He*ln expected justice but*ln saw injustice; he*ln expected righteousness but*ln heard cries of despair.
Judah’s Sins Denounced
Woe*pn to those who add house to house and*ln join field to field until*ln there is no more room and*ln you alone are left in the land.
I*p heard the Lord*s of Armies say: Indeed,*pn many houses will become desolate, grand*ln and lovely ones without inhabitants.
For*ln a ten-acre vineyard will yield only*ln six gallons of wine, and*ln ten bushels of seed will yield only*ln one bushel of grain.
Woe*pn to those who rise early in the morning in*ln pursuit of beer, who*ln linger into the evening, inflamed*ln by wine.
At*ln their feasts they have lyre, harp, tambourine,*ln flute, and wine. They*ln do not perceive the Lord’s*s actions, and*ln they do not see the work of his hands.
Therefore*pn my people will go into exile because*ln they lack knowledge; her*ln dignitaries are starving, and*ln her masses are parched with thirst.
Therefore*ln Sheol enlarges its throat and*ln opens wide its enormous jaws, and*ln down go Zion’s dignitaries, her masses, her*ln crowds, and those who celebrate in her!
Humanity*ln is brought low, each person is humbled, and*ln haughty eyes are humbled.
But*ln the Lord*s of Armies is exalted by his justice, and*ln the holy God demonstrates his holiness through his righteousness.
Lambs*ln will graze as*ln if in their own pastures, and*ln resident aliens will eat among*ln the ruins of the rich.
Woe*pn to those who drag iniquity with*ln cords of deceit and*ln pull sin along with cart ropes,
to*ln those who say, “Let*ln him hurry up and do his work quickly so*ln that we can see it! Let*ln the plan of the Holy One of Israel take place so*ln that we can know it!”
Woe*ln to those who call evil good and*ln good evil, who*ln substitute darkness for light and*ln light for darkness, who*ln substitute bitter for sweet and*ln sweet for bitter.
Woe*ln to those who consider themselves wise and*ln judge themselves clever.
Woe*ln to those who are heroes at drinking wine, who*ln are champions at pouring beer,
who*ln acquit the guilty for a bribe and*ln deprive the innocent of justice.

Therefore,*pn as a tongue of fire consumes straw and*ln as dry grass shrivels in the flame, so*ln their roots will become like something rotten and*ln their blossoms will blow away like dust, for*ln they have rejected the*ln instruction of the Lord*s of Armies, and*ln they have despised the*ln word of the Holy One of Israel.

Therefore*ln the Lord’s*s anger burned against his people. He*ln raised his hand against them and struck them; the*ln mountains quaked, and*ln their corpses were like garbage in the streets. In*ln all this, his anger has not turned away, and*ln his hand is still raised to strike.
He*pn raises a signal flag for the distant nations and*ln whistles for them from the ends of the earth. Look -*ln how quickly and swiftly they come!
None*ln of them grows weary or stumbles; no*ln one slumbers or sleeps. No*ln belt is loose and*ln no sandal strap broken.
Their*ln arrows are sharpened, and*ln all their bows strung. Their*ln horses’ hooves are like flint; their*ln chariot wheels are like a whirlwind.
Their*ln roaring is like a lion’s; they*ln roar like young lions; they*ln growl and seize their prey and*ln carry it off, and*ln no one can rescue it.
On*ln that day they will roar over it, like*ln the roaring of the sea. When*ln one looks at the land, there*ln will be darkness and distress; light*ln will be obscured by clouds.
